content.description: A slabby problem that might be v2 if you are under 6 feet tall. Start with a low down smear on nothing, grab and undercling and a crimp rail, then high step foot-hand match to glory. Really fun and very delicate.

Tall! Overhung! Technical! Shaded! Get on it!

On the Spirit Heal boulder, this line starts low on jugs in the center of the boulder. The jugs give way quickly to good crimps and those recede to bad crimps. Take a left turn and follow the semi-horizontal fingertips crack up until it widens to a jug and make a move for the top.

I did not complete this route as I was too excited about the new area to work long on a problem that is at my limit. I would imagine that such a well defined line has been climbed, and there was definitely chalk on the start holds. If anyone has completed this climb and wants to name it and confirm the grade, let me know. Otherwise I'll get to it on my next visit.
content.protection: A couple pads or a good friend to move one around for you.
content.location: The tallest, overhung boulder in the area. You cannot miss it.

content.description:
Somewhat separated from the rest of the boulders in the field, this is one of the taller problems in the area. The crack starts small low down and widens quickly to hands, then fists and finally goes wide less than half way up. The feet are excellent. For the most fun, resist the urge to start on the high jug. Plug a hand jam and start on the small feet before giving into the deliciously good holds and solid feet for the rest of the way up.

Walk off the back.
content.protection: Two pads if you aren't solid, but it's V1 with great feet and jugs at the top.
content.location: Look directly uphill from the main set of boulders. You will see several tall formations covered in chicken heads. Â This one is the furthest up the hill, behind the others. The crack will come into view as you walk up hill towards it. The direct path to the crack along your line of site involves wading through manzanita bushes and some very difficult scrambling. It is not recommended, though possible. Instead, look right of the lowest down formations and you will see some granite slab. Make your way up onto it, then turn back left and work your way up to the crack. You will still have to wade through manzanitas.
